features.title: When the user is opening a published app
features.description:
Rules:
* If the user has missing connections or capabilities that aren't consented to, the permissions screen should show up
* When the permissions screen is approved, the rest of the app will be loaded
* When the permissions screen is canceled, any previously set capabilities are reset, and the app is exited
* Updates the connection display data
* Adds a connection
* Fix a connection

features.title: Ensure small devices are locked to portrait while in the App Host
features.description:
To provide a better user experience devices with small screens need to be restricted to only using portrait mode.
The UI doesn't support a good experience while the keyboard is visible and in landscape. This restriction is not
applied however while inside a published app.

Rules:
    * If a small device (phone) lock orientation to portrait while on the signin screen an other App Host screens.
    * If not a small device allow rotation
    * Ensure rules are re-applied when returning to the App Host after closing a published app.
    * If deep linking to another application then honor the orientation of the new app.

features.title: Ensure published apps orientation settings are enabled
features.description:
Published apps have the option to set the orientation options to suit their application.

Rules:
    Apps can set the following options:
      * Define the default orientation ie Portrait/Landscape
      * Enable locking the orientation preventing the device from rotating

features.title: Open a cordova published App using a WebView
features.description:
Published apps are currently built to use Cordova, as part of the migration to react-native
Existing Cordova apps should be runnable within a React Native WebView. If an application is not
installed locally then it will be loaded from the Web, in this situation sandboxing is not required.

Requirements:
* Support passing messages from WebView to host
* Support passing message from Host to WebView
* Ensure WebView can only access files it has access to (sandboxing)
* Support loading files from multiple locations (url rewrite)

features.title: Visual component that can be used to render content as flyout on top of the screen relative to another element.
features.description:
Horizontal Position Rules:
- Right position should anchor to the right of the parent and flyout to the left as long as the flyout does not overflow the minimum distance from the screen edge.
- If flying out left overflows the minimum distance from the screen edge, anchor to the parent X and flyout to the right.
- If flying out left and right both over flow the minimum distance from the screen edge, choose the flyout direction based on which direction has the least screen overflow.
- If the flyout overflows the screen, the flyout should render such that the overflow direction is adjusted back to the minimum distance from the screen edge.
- When matching the parent size, the right should anchor to the right of the parent and the width/max width should match the parent width.

Vertical Position Rules:
- Top position should anchor to the bottom of the parent and flyout to the bottom as long as the flyout does not overflow the minimum distance from the screen edge.
- If flying out down overflows the minimum distance from the screen edge, anchor to the parent Y and flyout to the top.
- If flying out top and bottom both over flow the minimum distance from the screen edge, choose the flyout direction based on which direction has the least screen overflow.
- If the flyout overflows the screen, the flyout should render such that the overflow direction is adjusted back to the minimum distance from the screen edge.

When deserializing the base 64 encoded string, the string should be decoded first and then converted back to ArrayBuffer.

features.title: ScreenReaderFocusManager
features.description:
Purpose: Manage components that change UI flow and returns focus to components as we navigate back

Rules:
* Track components based on the screen they are created on
* Return focus to the latest component activated for a given screen
* Remove a tracked item (this happens when focus is returned or dispose is directly called on the tracked component (ex. on componentWillUnmount))
* When the screen changes, return the focus to the most recent tracked component for the current screen

scenarios.description:

* If there is a connection already available, skip
* If there is no api associated with the connection, skip
* If it is an on premise connection, skip
* If it is not a first party api, skip

scenarios.title: Connections are sorted according to the following rules
scenarios.description:
* If the shared connection id on the reference is equal to the id of the connection, that connection goes first
* IF there is a gateway hint on the reference, then the connection with the matching gateway object goes first
* If both connections have a display name, then they are sorted alphabetically by display name
* Otherwise, sort it alphabetically by id

features.title: When managing connections for a published app
features.description:
Rules:
* Fetches the most up to date connection information for the specified app and connections
* The connection display data is populated correctly
* All the user's connections are filtered and sorted to determine if they can be used by the app
* A connection is selected to be the one to be displayed as default
* Single sign on connections can be created silently
* Connections can be matched to their corresponding connection reference
* Connections can be saved for the app

scenarios.title: Ensure NPS is not triggered on iOS when
scenarios.description:
- the NPS feature gate is on
- the platform OS is iOS
- the NPSOnIOS feature gate is off

This is due to PowerApps pricing information being accessible
from links/buttons in the NPS dialog which will cause Apple
to reject the app when they validate the store submission.

scenarios.title: When sending a request with a PABinary body
scenarios.description:
- Make sure we explicitly set the Content-Type header according to whatever is in the PABinary.contentType.
- Support the sourceTypes currently supported by the SendHttpPipelinePlugin v1.

When the body is an ArrayBuffer, and no default Content-Type, the base content type will get set to an octet-stream.

examples.title: Controller action should be able to throw an error and the handler should automatically serialize it.

scenarios.title: Controller action should be able to throw an error and the handler should automatically serialize it.
scenarios.description:
Errors thrown by the actual controller should get serialized too.
Default serialization is done even if the plugin metadata hasn't been swapped yet.
Message-only errors end up getting serialized the same no matter the errorTypesSetVersion used.
Custom serialized errors should get default serialization when the errorTypesSetVersion is not at least the first version which the error was serialized.
e.g. ServiceError should only get serialized with the custom serializedVersion if the errorTypesSetVersion is at least 2.

features.title: ActionsControllerPluginHandler should serialize plugin Errors as Cordova error results.
features.description:
The ActionsControllerPluginHandler represents a CordovaPlugin implementation that acts as a service router
for one or more LocalPlugin Controller instances. Each Controller is bound to a single major version.
The handler provides common overhead tasks like:
- Routing messages based on service version and actionName.
- Validating action args and result values against the serviceDefinition.
- Provide generalized error handling and serialization; the controller only needs to throw an error.

features.title: Provide a communication channel between the published app and the runtime host plugins
features.description:
Existing runtime plugins in the host require an implementation of the ICommunicationChannel.
The CordovaCommunicationChannel implements this interface and is a wrapper over the message pipeline

scenarios.title: Workflow of calling a service action and either the serviceName or actionName isn't found
scenarios.description:
- errorTypesSetVersion: Gives coverage showing that the expected serialized error should not matter whether the version metadata has been exchanged.
    For the CordovaPluginServiceBase, we are at a higher-layer of infrastructure so we don't want to depend on the version metadata being exchanged
    or not. This is why the default errorTypesSetVersion is always set to 0.

scenarios.description:
Given:
serviceName = AppHostPlugin
actionName = notifyHostToAppCommandCompleted - The action used when the App notifies the Host with the command's result.
commandName = mockCmd

features.title: AppHostPluginHandler should support all regular Plugin Actions.
features.description:
Note: This feature is only one part of what AppHostPlugin does. It is targeted for testing just the regular plugin actions,
and does not cover any of the AppToHost or HostToApp command functionality.

The regular actions on the AppHostPlugin cover the following functionality:
- Actions related to runtime error handling.
- Actions related to executing App to Host commands.
- Actions related to sending Host to App commands, and receiving the results.

scenarios.title: Published App makes requests to the AppHttpClientPlugin with different arguments.
scenarios.description:
This scenario tests the communication system from the PublishedApp to the AppHost. Because the Plugin makes
a Cordova.exec call to a handler via a communication channel, which then gets routed through the service via abus,
this scenario detects whether anything within this communication pipeline has changed (i.e. added a new action name,
modified the action arguments, or changed the return type).

-action: Name of the action invoked from the service.
-actionArgs: The args parameters that were passed through with the action name.
-expectedRequest: The expected request parameters passed to the ISendHttpPipeline.sendHttpAsync function (this does not include the responseType).
-stubbedTargetReturnValue: The return value of the call to the internal stubbed call.
-expectedPluginReturnValue: Expected return value of the entire plugin call to the action name.

scenarios.title: Published App makes requests to the AppHttpClientPlugin.sendHttpAsync enabling the 'specialProcessingNeeded' workflow.
scenarios.description:
The plugin in the app sets a requestSource property on the request action arg to indicate the app can handle the new
response body returned by this workflow. RN host will only enable this special processing when the requests's responseType
is also set to 'arraybuffer'.

This is essentially an unofficial V2 of the sendHttpAsync action that will only work on new RN clients that support it.
A host need not handle this setting, as the new apps will just default to assume the body is an ArrayBuffer.

Note: This workflow does NOT enable the response to also specify an app-relative url so we will be mocking most of the request.

-actionArgs: The args parameters that were passed through with the action name.
-expectedRequest: The expected request parameters passed to the ISendHttpPipeline.sendHttpAsync function (this does not include the responseType).
-stubbedTargetReturnValue: The return value of the call to the internal stubbed call.
-expectedPluginReturnValue: Expected return value of the entire plugin call to the action name.

features.title: Making http requests from within the published app
features.description:
Published apps that make http requests will send them via the host to the AppHttpClientPluginService.

Rules:
* Send generic http request
* Send generic http request and ignore the response
* Send http request expecting a text response
* Send http request expecting a json response
* Send http request expecting a blob response
* Temporary folder for files request is deleted when the application is closed

features.title: Allow the ability to take pictures with an inline video preview
features.description:
Published Apps support the ability to add a camera control that will provide real-time preview within the page.
This allows the user to overlay other elements over the video stream.

Rules:
* Start and stop video preview
* Stream a video preview to the published App
* Snap a picture and return to the published App

Design:
* preview: the plugin captures an image from the camera and stores the data in memory, using the settings provided during initialization.
  The WebView obtains this image via the custom URLProtocol http://pa-camera/preview. This eliminates the need to write the data to disk for previews.
  As part of the preview a script is executed in the WebView that updates the image around 30 frames per second. When stopping the preview another script
  is sent to the WebView that stops the updates.
* capture: the images is sent via a message as a base64 encoded image using the settings provided during initialization.

features.title: Allow published apps to respond to changes in keyboard visibility
features.description:
When an input box receives focus within a published app the published app needs to know if the keyboard becomes visible and
if so what the height of the keyboard is so that it can move the input box above the visible keyboard.

Rules:
* Allow published apps to register for keyboard visibility events
* Notify published apps when a keyboard visibility event occurs after registering

features.title: Allow the ability to record audio
features.description:
Published Apps support the ability to add a microphone control that will provide the ability to record audio to a file (temp).

Rules:
* Start recording
* Stop recording
* Dispose of microphone resources

Design:
* Android has restrictions on mixed content to the extent that its not possible to load a file:// when the pages originates from the web.
  To overcome this limitation a pseudo scheme was introduced http://temp which maps to the physical location of the apps cache directory.
  This allows native code to write the the cache dir and have the installed app reference the local cache via http://temp/. The cache dir was added
  as part of the app sandbox.
* This design relies on mostly native code to achieve its goals, as such these tests do not cover this. Integration tests should cover this in the future.

examples.title: Plugin should preserve function signature through the Plugin communication pipeline.

scenarios.title: Plugin should preserve function signature through the Plugin communication pipeline.
scenarios.description:
This scenario tests the communication system from the PublishedApp to the AppHost. Because the Plugin makes
a Cordova.exec call to a handler via a communication channel, which then gets routed through the service via abus,
this scenario detects whether anything within this communication pipeline has changed (i.e. added a new action name,
modified the action arguments, or changed the return type).

actionName: Name of the action invoked from the service.
actionArgs: The args parameters that were passed through with the actionName.
expectedTargetArgs: The args parameters passed into the internal action (stubbed).
openUrlSucceeds: Determines whether the call to openUrlAsync succeeds or throws. "undefined" if canOpenUrlAsync returns false.
expectedPluginReturnValue: Expected return value of the entire plugin call to the action name.

features.title: Launch a URL from a published app
features.description:
Published Apps support the ability to define a launch function which launches a program based on the protocol and URL provided by the user

Rules:
* If the protocol is supported, then it will launch the program and return true.
* If the protocol is not supported, then it will attempt to launch the program and will return false.

scenarios.title: Creating a hard link between files in resource folder and files in installed app folder

features.title: Installing a PowerApp on an iOS device
features.description:
Published app needs to be installed on a device to optimize performance and support offline mode.
On iOS devices, creating a hard link between player resource folder and installed app folder allows the app to use the files in
player resource folder without having to copy them over to the installed app folder which saves installation time.
For other platforms, we use URL redirect to achive the same result.

features.title: Manage and cache device capabilities and auth resources for the published app
features.description:
Rules:
* Check if the user needs to consent for the capabilities for a specific app from the cache
* Get the capabilities that the user already consented to use for a specific app from the cache
* Set the capabilities that the user just consented to for a specific app in the cache
* Delete capabilities that the user previously consented to and now has revoked from the cache
